revision.text:
A '''research assistant''' is a researcher employed, often on a temporary contract,<ref name="BL" >{{cite web |url=http://www.eui.eu/ProgrammesAndFellowships/AcademicCareersObservatory/AcademicCareersbyCountry/BelgiumFlanders.aspx |title=European University Institute - Belgium Flanders, Academic Career Structure |publisher=www.eui.eu |accessdate=2010-05-11 }}</ref> by a [[university]] or a research institute, for the purpose of assisting in academic [[research]]. Research assistants are not independent and not directly responsible for the outcome of the research and are responsible to a supervisor or principal investigator. Research assistants are often educated to degree level<ref name=cam-ra>{{cite web|author=University of Cambridge|date=March 2003|url=http://www.admin.cam.ac.uk/offices/hr/reward/pd33/generic/researchassistant.pdf |title=Generic Role Profile Research Assistant|accessdate=18 May 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.admin.cam.ac.uk%2Foffices%2Fhr%2Freward%2Fpd33%2Fgeneric%2Fresearchassistant.pdf&date=2010-05-18 |archivedate=18 May 2010}}</ref> and might be enrolled in a [[Postgraduate education|postgraduate degree]] program and simultaneously teach.<ref name="BL"/><ref name=ebs-ra>{{cite web |author = European Business School |date = 11 May 2010 |url = http://www.academicjobseu.com/content/jobsearch/job_advert.asp?jobadid=7418 |title = Research Assistant - Supply Chain Management Institute |accessdate = 18 May 2010 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5pokyyW60?url=http://www.academicjobseu.com/content/jobsearch/job_advert.asp?jobadid=7418 |archivedate = May 18, 2010 |df = }}</ref><ref name=UTeM-ra>{{cite web |author = Universiti Teknikal Malaysia Melaka |date = 9 March 2008 |url = http://www.scholarshipnet.info/postgraduate/malaysia-research-assistant-position-at-universiti-teknikal-malaysia-melaka-utem/ |title = Research Assistant Position at Universiti Teknikal Malaysia Melaka |accessdate = 18 May 2010 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5polOUGKh?url=http://www.scholarshipnet.info/postgraduate/malaysia-research-assistant-position-at-universiti-teknikal-malaysia-melaka-utem/ |archivedate = May 18, 2010 |df = }}</ref>
==Undergraduate and post-doctoral level== Although a research assistant is normally appointed at graduate level, undergraduates are also sometimes appointed to support research.
Similarly, someone who has recently been awarded a doctoral degree may hold a temporary appointment as a ''[[Postdoctoral research|postdoctoral research assistant]]''.
==Clinical research assistant== A '''clinical research assistant''' is employed by a hospital or medical research centre, who is involved in the administration of [[clinical trials]]. He or she may assist a senior investigator with recruiting and enrolling research subjects, as well as with correspondence and grant applications.
==See also== * [[Academic freedom]] * [[Graduate student]] * [[Research associate]] * [[Researcher]]
==References==
<references/>
{{Academic positions}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Research Assistant}}
[[Category:Academic administration]] [[Category:Education and training occupations]]
[[nl:Promovendus]] [[sl:Asistent]]

{{refimprove|date=September 2014}}
'''School Captain''' or '''School Pupil Leader''' is a [[student]] appointed or [[election|elected]] to lead the student body of a school.
It is similar to "[[Student Body President]]" in the [[United States]], it is the senior representative of a school's pupils, and the school, in the community.
School captains are mainly found in [[British Empire]] legacy school systems: [[Australia]], [[Canada]], [[New Zealand]], [[South Africa]], [[India]], [[Zimbabwe]].
In the election the students perform a speech in front of the school and tell the audience about their involvement and personal qualities, the students (audience) are asked to vote who they think the position should go to, but in some cases the teachers have the final decision due to the student thinking it is a popularity contest so the school knows the student can represent the school with success and ultimate behaviour.
==Role and Responsibilities== The school captain can act as a liaison between the students at large and the faculty staff, and between the school and the community. The captain may also represent the school in sporting events against other schools, this is more common with private schools.The responsibilities of a school captain are: - serving as a good role model for the other students - speaking at formal occasions and assemblies
Usually, School Captains are appointed with a badge, one that is evidence of their status.
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:School terminology]]

revision.text:
{{infobox Museum |name=Science History Institute |former_name= Center for the History of Chemistry (1982-1992)
Chemical Heritage Foundation (1992- February 1, 2018) |image = File:Science History Institute 2018 sneak peek 13.JPG |caption = (2018) |established={{Start date|1982|01|22|df=y}} |location=315 [[Chestnut Street (Philadelphia)|Chestnut Street]], [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]], US 19106 | type = | accreditation = | key_holdings = [[Alchemy]], [[History of chemistry]], [[History of science]], [[Instrumentation]] | collections = | collection_size = | visitors = | founder = [[Arnold Thackray]] | director = | president = [[Robert G. W. Anderson]] | chairperson = |publictransit = {{bus icon|12px}} {{rint|septa|60px}} [[SEPTA]] bus: 21, 42, 57 | website = {{URL|http://www.sciencehistory.org/}} }} The '''Science History Institute''' is an institution that preserves and promotes understanding of the [[history of science]]. Located in [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]], it includes a [[library]], [[museum]], [[archive]], research center and [[conference center]]. It was founded in 1982 as a joint venture of the [[American Chemical Society]] and the [[University of Pennsylvania]], as the '''Center for the History of Chemistry''' ('''CHOC'''). The [[American Institute of Chemical Engineers]] (AIChE) became a co-founder in 1984. It was renamed the '''Chemical Heritage Foundation''' ('''CHF''') in 1992, and moved two years later to the institution's current location, 315 Chestnut Street in [[Old City, Philadelphia|Old City]].{{cite journal|title=The History of CHF|journal=Chemical Heritage: Newsmagazine of the Chemical Heritage Foundation|date=2000-02-01|volume=18|issue=1|pages=16–22}} On December 1, 2015, CHF merged with the [[Life Sciences Foundation]], creating an organization that covers "the history of the life sciences and biotechnology together with the history of the chemical sciences and engineering."{{cite web|title=History|url=https://www.sciencehistory.org/history|website=Science History Institute|accessdate=27 March 2018|date=2016-05-31}}{{cite news|title=CHF and LSF Announce Merger|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/chf-and-lsf-announce-merger-300159747.html|accessdate=19 November 2016|work=PR Newswire|date=Oct 14, 2015}} As of February 1, 2018, the organization was renamed the Science History Institute, to reflect its wider range of historical interests, from chemical sciences and engineering to the life sciences and biotechnology.{{cite news|last1=Salisbury|first1=Stephan|title=Chemical Heritage Foundation is morphing into the Science History Institute|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/entertainment/arts/chemical-heritage-foundation-science-history-institute-philadelphia-20180103.html|accessdate=1 February 2018|work=Philadelphia Inquirer|date=January 3, 2018}} The Institute focuses not only on the [[history of chemistry]] but also on the [[history of science]], the [[history of technology]], trends in [[research and development]], the impact of [[science#Science and society|science on society]], and relationships between science and art, among other subjects. It supports a community of research scholars and an oral history program. As of 2012, it was the largest US grantor of research fellowships for the history of science.{{cite journal|last1=Gussman|first1=Neil|title=A philanthropic career: Arnold Beckman and chemical heritage|journal=Chemistry in Australia|date=2012|volume=October|url=http://www.chemheritage.org/Downloads/News-and-Press/ChemistryInAustralia_Oct2012_Beckman.pdf|pages=32–33|accessdate=10 March 2015|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304050805/http://www.chemheritage.org/Downloads/News-and-Press/ChemistryInAustralia_Oct2012_Beckman.pdf |archivedate=2016-03-04 |df= }}{{cite web|title=Honoring the Othmers: Generosity, Vision, and a Transformative Gift|url=http://www.chemheritage.org/about/history/chf-founders/2013-02-14-othmer-gift.aspx|website=Chemical Heritage Foundation|accessdate=11 March 2015|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160712182322/http://www.chemheritage.org/about/history/chf-founders/2013-02-14-othmer-gift.aspx |archivedate=2016-07-12|df= }} ==History== The idea of creating "a library of reference and a chemical museum" in the United States can be found in the Proceedings of the first meeting of the [[American Chemical Society]] in 1876.{{cite journal|title=The American Chemical Society: Proceedings of the first meeting for organization, New York, April 6, 1876|journal=The American Chemist|date=1876|volume=7|issue=11|pages=401–402|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KpMMAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA402|accessdate=19 March 2015|last1=Chandler|first1=Charles Frederick|last2=Chandler|first2=William Henry}} Impetus for the creation of the Science History Institute dates to 1976, when the [[United States Bicentennial|nation's bicentennial]] and the centennial of the American Chemical Society (ACS) stimulated interest in both history and chemistry. John H. Wotiz of the Division of the History of Chemistry of the ACS organized a session on the history of chemistry as part of the ACS centennial activities and was a strong proponent of a national center for historical chemistry.{{cite journal|last1=Reese|first1=K. M.|last2=Ritter|first2=Stephen|title=ACS History Society Reaches 125th Birthday|journal=[[Chemical & Engineering News]]|volume=79|issue=13|page=March 26, 2001|url=http://pubs.acs.org/cen/125th/html/7913history.html|accessdate=11 March 2015}}{{cite journal|last=Wotiz|first=John H.|title=History of Chemistry: The ACS Centre in Philadelphia |journal=Chemical Heritage|date=2000|volume=18|issue=3|pages=45–46}}{{cite web|title=John H. Wotiz (1919–2001)|url=http://www.scs.illinois.edu/~mainzv/HIST/awards/Dexter%20Papers/WotizDexterBioJJB.pdf|publisher=Division of History of Chemistry of the American Chemical Society|accessdate=1 January 2006}} ===Center for the History of Chemistry=== In 1979, the ACS formed a task force chaired by [[Ned D. Heindel]] to investigate the possibility of creating a national center for the history of chemistry. [[Arnold Thackray]], a professor in the Department of History and Sociology of Science at the University of Pennsylvania, and curator of the [[Edgar Fahs Smith]] Memorial Collection on the history of chemistry at the University of Pennsylvania, argued for the formation of such a center in Philadelphia. He was able to obtain promises of private support from chemist [[John C. Haas]], and institutional support from the [[Dow Chemical Company]] and [[DuPont]]. In December 1981 the ACS approved the establishment of the Center for the History of Chemistry, with support of $50,000 per year for five years, in cooperation with the University of Pennsylvania, which was to provide an equivalent in goods and services. An agreement to create the Center for the History of Chemistry was signed by officers of the American Chemical Society and the University of Pennsylvania on January 22 and 26, 1982.{{cite journal|title=Center for History of Chemistry Created|journal=CHOC News|date=1982|volume=1|issue=1|pages=1–3, 11}} A policy council was appointed by the sponsoring institutions to oversee routine operations of the center, and [[Arnold Thackray]] was appointed part-time director of the center on April 29, 1982. The official inauguration of the center was held on March 11, 1983.{{cite journal|title=Center for History of Chemistry Inaugurated|journal=CHOC News|date=1983|volume=1|issue=3|pages=1–3}} The Center's first home was in several vacant basement rooms on the [[University of Pennsylvania]] campus.{{cite web|last=Gussman|first=Neil|title=The Power of John C. Haas's Good Name|url=http://www.chemheritage.org/about/history/chf-founders/2011-05-16-john-c-haas.aspx|publisher=Chemical Heritage Foundation|accessdate=23 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160712182325/http://www.chemheritage.org/about/history/chf-founders/2011-05-16-john-c-haas.aspx|archivedate=July 12, 2016}} Its "immediate aims" included gathering oral histories of important chemists and inventorying papers and manuscripts in repositories throughout the country to map "the largely unexplored territory of the history of chemistry and chemical technology." A National Advisory Board was also formed from a wide-ranging group of people in academia and industry. In 1982, its members included John C. Haas, historians [[Margaret W. Rossiter]] and [[Alfred D. Chandler, Jr.]] and at least three [[Nobel Prize]] winners, [[Christian B. Anfinsen]], [[Herbert C. Brown]], and [[Glenn T. Seaborg]]. The [[American Institute of Chemical Engineers]] (AIChE) became a co-founder of the Center, signing an agreement on August 27 and 28, 1984.{{cite journal|title=American Institute of Chemical Engineers Joins CHOC Endeavor|journal=CHOC News|date=1984|volume=2|issue=1|pages=1–3}} In addition, the institution began to establish relationships with affiliated organizations such as [[The Chemists' Club]], the [[American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology]], the [[American Association of Textile Chemists and Colorists]], the [[Electrochemical Society]] and the [[American Society for Mass Spectrometry]].{{cite book|last1=Bowden|first1=Mary Ellen|last2=Flaumenhaft|first2=Daniel|title=Chemistry is electric!|date=1997|publisher=Chemical Heritage Foundation|location=Philadelphia|isbn=978-0-941901-17-8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6_0UvIZFypkC&pg=PA1965}} As early as 1983, the Center for the History of Chemistry expressed an interest in "The Conservation of Historic American Chemical Instruments", in discussions of a possible joint project with the [[Smithsonian Institution|Smithsonian]]. However, the center did not yet have exhibition or collections space to allow for the acquisition of any but the most limited quantities of documents.{{cite journal|title=The Conservation of Historic American Chemical Instruments|journal=CHOC News|date=1983|volume=1|issue=3|page=12}} The center did curate a number of traveling exhibitions by collaborating with other organizations, including "Joseph Priestley: Enlightened Chemist",{{cite web|title=Joseph Priestley, enlightened chemist an exhibit celebrating the 250th birthday of Joseph Priestley|url=http://ihm.nlm.nih.gov/luna/servlet/detail/NLMNLM~1~1~101437807~151872:Joseph-Priestley,-enlightened-chemi|place=Philadelphia|publisher=Center for History of Chemistry|date=1983}} "Polymers and People",{{cite book|last1=Elliott|first1=Eric|title=Polymers and People: An Informal History|date=1986|publisher=The Center for the History of Chemistry|location=Philadelphia|edition=1st}} "Scaling Up",{{cite journal|last1=Smith|first1=John K.|title="Scaling up: Science, Engineering, and the American Chemical Industry"-Center for History of Chemistry|journal=Technology and Culture|date=1986|volume=27|issue=4|pages=832–834|jstor=3105331|doi=10.2307/3105331}}{{cite book|last1=Heitmann|first1=John Alfred|last2=Rhees|first2=David J.|title=Scaling up: science, engineering, and the American chemical industry|date=1990|publisher=Beckman Center for the History of Chemistry, University of Pennsylvania|location=Philadelphia, PA, US}} and "Chemical Education in the United States".{{cite journal|last1=Lewenstein|first1=Bruce V.|title="To improve our knowledge in nature and arts": A history of chemical education in the United States|journal=Journal of Chemical Education|date=January 1989|volume=66|issue=1|pages=37|doi=10.1021/ed066p37|bibcode=1989JChEd..66...37L}} ====Arnold and Mabel Beckman Center for the History of Chemistry (BCHOC)==== During the 1980s, the center came to the attention of [[Arnold Orville Beckman]]. The [[Arnold and Mabel Beckman Foundation]] provided a $2 million challenge grant in 1986 to stimulate expansion of the center as a research institute, the Arnold and Mabel Beckman Center for the History of Chemistry (BCHOC).{{cite web|title=Arnold O. Beckman and CHF: A Brief History|url=http://www.chemheritage.org/about/history/chf-founders/2012-08-27-arnold-beckman.aspx|website=Chemical Heritage Foundation|accessdate=12 March 2015|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160712182319/http://www.chemheritage.org/about/history/chf-founders/2012-08-27-arnold-beckman.aspx|archivedate=July 12, 2016}} Beckman challenged the center to define its mission more broadly, reaching out to academic, professional and trade organizations, and including biochemistry, materials science, petrochemicals, pharmaceuticals and instrumentation within its mandate.{{cite book | isbn = 978-0-941901-23-9 |author1=Arnold Thackray |author2=Minor Myers, Jr. ; foreword by James D. Watson. | year = 2000 | publisher = Chemical Heritage Foundation | location = Philadelphia, Pa. | title = Arnold O. Beckman : one hundred years of excellence}} The National Foundation for History of Chemistry was established in 1987 as a supporting Pennsylvania nonprofit.{{cite book|last1=Achilladelis|first1=Basil|last2=Bowden|first2=Mary Ellen|title=Structures of life|date=1989|publisher=The Center|location=Philadelphia, Pa.|isbn=9780941901079}} The renamed Beckman Center began a major capital campaign, listing as its needs "offices, an exhibit gallery, a reading room, library stacks, and archives and storage areas."{{cite journal|title=CHOC becomes the Beckman Center - A Landmark Event|journal=The Beckman Center for the History of Chemistry News|date=1988|volume=5|issue=1|page=1,11,14}} It celebrated its inauguration on November 5, 1987.{{cite journal|last=Bohning|first=James J.|title=Chemical Instrumentation Symposium Inaugurates Beckman Center|journal=The Beckman Center for the History of Chemistry News|date=1988|volume=5|issue=2|page=1,11–15}} With support from the American Chemical Society's "Campaign for Chemistry", the Center was able to move to 3401 Walnut Street, on the University of Pennsylvania campus, as of March 9, 1988.{{cite journal|last1=University of Pennsylvania|title=Moves to 3401 Walnut Street|journal=Almanac|date=March 15, 1988|volume=34|issue=25|url=http://www.upenn.edu/almanac/v34pdf/n25/031588.pdf}} ==== Othmer Library of Chemical History ==== In 1989, the Center received a further challenge grant, this time from [[Donald F. Othmer]] and his wife, Mildred Topp Othmer. Donald Othmer was a quiet chemical engineering professor from Polytechnic University in Brooklyn.{{cite news |first=Karen E. |last=Quinones Miller |title=Chemistry Foundation Here Finds Element Of Surprise A Professor Left It Millions |url=http://articles.philly.com/1998-07-14/news/25737042_1_chemical-heritage-foundation-chemical-engineering-chemistry-prize |quote=In 1982, when the Chemical Heritage Foundation was a fledgling research organization starting out with only $50,000, it asked chemical engineers and experts around the country to serve as advisers on its council of friends. One of those who accepted the invitation was [[Donald F. Othmer]], a chemical engineering professor at Polytechnic University in Brooklyn, an unassuming scholar who originally hailed from Omaha, Neb. |work=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]] |date=July 14, 1988 |accessdate=2008-10-22 }} The Othmers donated $5 million towards the creation of the Othmer Library of Chemical History. Again, efforts to match the grant were supported by the National Foundation for History of Chemistry and the American Chemical Society's Campaign for Chemistry. The new library was further supported by the donation of 8,500 monographs, textbooks and reference works from The Chemists' Club of New York.{{cite journal|last=Price|first=Charles C.|title=Making History: The Challenge Met - And the Challenge Ahead |journal=The Beckman Center for the History of Chemistry News|date=1989|volume=6|issue=2|pages=1–2}}{{cite journal|title=The Donald F. & Mildred Topp Othmer Library of Chemical History |journal=The Beckman Center for the History of Chemistry News|date=1989|volume=6|issue=2|page=insert}} ===Chemical Heritage Foundation=== On July 1, 1992, the National Foundation for History of Chemistry changed its name to the Chemical Heritage Foundation, in recognition of the international nature of chemical history.{{cite journal|title=The Chemical Heritage Foundation |journal=The Beckman Center for the History of Chemistry News|date=1992|volume=9|issue=2|pages=1, 16}} By 1994, the [[First National Bank (Philadelphia)|First National Bank]] at 315 Chestnut Street was being discussed as a possible permanent home for the Beckman Center and Othmer Library.{{cite journal|title=CHF Approaches Independence |journal=Chemical Heritage|date=1992|volume=11|issue=2|page=1}} The institution was able to purchase the bank and nearby property in 1995 in part through a matching grant from Donald Othmer. Soon afterward, its endowment was expanded by a bequest from Othmer's estate. The Chemical Heritage Foundation moved to 315 Chestnut Street on February 1, 1996.{{cite journal|title=CHF on the Move! |journal=Chemical Heritage|date=1996|volume=13|issue=2|pages=7–8}} The buildings were renovated by Richard Conway Meyer occurred in two main phases over the next few years.{{cite journal|title=The Chemical Heritage Foundation: A growing resource for the chemical community|journal=Chemistry International|date=1998|volume=20|issue=1|url=http://www.iupac.org/publications/ci/1998/january/heritage.pdf|accessdate=18 March 2015}} Phase 1, providing temporary office space and book storage, was completed in 1998. Phase 2, a move to more permanent facilities, was completed in 2000.{{cite journal|title=CHF Headquarters - Under construction |journal=Chemical Heritage|date=1998|volume=16|issue=2|pages=13}} Phase 3, construction of the adjoining Ullyot conference space for meetings and events, began soon after.{{cite journal|last=Asiamah|first=Akua|title=Groundbreaking ceremony kicks off 2000 Ullyot Lecture |journal=Chemical Heritage|date=2000|volume=18|issue=4|pages=10–11}} ====Creating a public museum==== [[File:CHF P1000361 Chemical Heritage Foundation Exterior.jpg | thumb | right | Chemical Heritage Foundation building]] [[File:"Old Faithful" bakelite cooker.jpg|thumb|right| "Old Faithful" bakelite cooker model, in museum]] Acquisition of a permanent building finally made it possible for the institution to develop "a public museum and display area".{{cite journal|title=CHF Move to Independence Park Draws Near |journal= Chemical Heritage|date=1995|volume=12|issue=2|page=3}}{{cite journal|title=A Museum of Chemical Progress: A Future Option at CHF |journal= Chemical Heritage|date=1995|volume=13|issue=1|page=7}} One possible focus was the history of instrumentation. As early as 1989, the Beckman Center had requested the loan or gift of [[Beckman Instruments]] such as the Beckman [[pH meter]] and the [[DU spectrophotometer]] for display at the Center.{{cite journal|title=Wanted: Beckman Instruments |journal=The Beckman Center for the History of Chemistry News|date=1989|volume=6|issue=3|page=9}} Some of those instruments were included in an instrumentation exhibition organized by W. Richard Howe of the University of Pittsburgh for the [[Pittsburgh Conference on Analytical Chemistry and Applied Spectroscopy]] (PITTCON) in 1994, and expanded in 1999.{{cite journal|title=Pittcon looks back at 50 years |journal= Chemical Heritage|date=1999|volume=17|issue=1|page=35}} In the early 1990s, inspired by John Ferraro, a committee was formed within the [[Society for Applied Spectroscopy]] (SAS), to pursue the creation of an instrumentation museum. Edward Brame and other members of that committee connected with Arnold Thackray and formed the nucleus of the institution's Chemical Instrumentation Museum Group (CIMG) in 1994.{{cite journal|url=http://images.alfresco.advanstar.com/alfresco_images/pharma/2014/08/22/5a1317cb-fafc-4c50-b557-e198e0f0fd52/article-31339.pdf |title=History of the Chemical Heritage Scientific Instrumentation Museum|first1=John R. |last1=Ferraro|first2=Edward G. |last2=Brame Jr|date=2002|volume=17|number=34|journal=Spectroscopy|accessdate=2 May 2014|quote=Note: This article predates the opening of the 2008 museum by several years; the museum exhibit discussed here was a temporary instrumentation exhibit from 2002, not the permanent museum of 2008. Although the authors refer to the "Chemical Heritage Foundation Scientific Instrumentation Museum", this was never the museum's official name.}}{{cite web|url=http://cen.acs.org/articles/87/i5/Setting-Record-Straight.html |first=Robert J. |last=Jarnutowski|title=Setting The Record Straight (letter to the editor)|date=2 Feb 2009|website=Chemical & Engineering News|accessdate=2 May 2014|quote=Note: The 2008 museum's focus on the history of science and science's impact on culture is much broader than an "educational display of pioneering and landmark instruments": equating the two is an apples-and-oranges comparison.}} In 1997, on the recommendation of the CIMG, the Chemical Heritage Foundation's board approved a collections policy for the acquisition of "historically significant chemical instruments and apparatus".{{cite journal|last=Swan|first=Elizabeth|title=A Letter from the Librarian |journal=Chemical Heritage|date=1997|volume=15|issue=1|page=15}} Instrumentation, however, was only one of several areas of interest as the institution began to expand its collections. =====Alchemical collections===== The Science History Institute is particularly interested in the origins of early science and chemistry.{{cite web|first=Neil|last= Gussman |url=http://www.chemheritage.org/discover/media/periodic-tabloid/2010-10-15-alchemy-in-the-news.aspx |title=Alchemy is Front-Page News, Again in the Science Times |date=2010-10-15 |accessdate=2013-06-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130814030245/http://www.chemheritage.org/discover/media/periodic-tabloid/2010-10-15-alchemy-in-the-news.aspx|archivedate=July 12, 2016}} Its varied holdings have considerable depth both in alchemical books and fine-art depictions of early modern alchemists. The institution's collection of alchemy-related artwork, one of the largest in the world, builds upon two significant collections.{{cite journal|last1=Gussman|first1=Neil|title=Chemical heritage in the US|journal=Chemistry in Australia|date=2012|pages=18–21|volume=October |url=http://www.chemheritage.org/Downloads/News-and-Press/ChemistryInAustralia_Oct2012_ChemHeritage.pdf |accessdate=10 March 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304052911/http://www.chemheritage.org/Downloads/News-and-Press/ChemistryInAustralia_Oct2012_ChemHeritage.pdf|archivedate=July 12, 2016}} Chester Garfield Fisher, founder of [[Fisher Scientific]], started collecting alchemical art in the 1920s. In 2000, his collection of alchemical paintings was donated by Fisher Scientific International to the Chemical Heritage Foundation.{{cite news|last1=Woo|first1=Kelly|title=The Art And Artifacts Of Alchemy Are Relics Of Science's Early Days|url=http://articles.philly.com/2000-06-19/living/25602745_1_art-collection-chemical-heritage-foundation-alchemy|accessdate=17 March 2015|work=The Philadelphia Inquirer|date=June 19, 2000}}{{cite book|last1=Principe|first1=Lawrence M.|last2=DeWitt|first2=Lloyd|title=Transmutations : alchemy in art : selected works from the Eddleman and Fisher collections at the Chemical Heritage Foundation|date=2002|publisher=Chemical Heritage Foundation|location=Philadelphia|isbn=9780941901321|page=37|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=A0YF0NobIY0C&pg=PA37|accessdate=18 March 2015}}{{cite journal|title=Famed Fisher Collection A Gift to CHF|journal=Chemical Heritage|date=2000|volume=18|issue=2|page=11}} In 2002, the institution received another gift from Roy Eddleman, founder of Spectrum Laboratories, whose collection contained paintings from the 17th, 18th, and 19th centuries.{{cite journal|last1=Morrissey|first1=Susan R.|title=ALCHEMICAL ART : Chemical Heritage Foundation gets addition to prized collection from Roy Eddleman|journal=Chemical & Engineering News|date=July 8, 2002|volume=80|issue=27|pages=30–32|url=http://pubs.acs.org/cen/science/8027/print/8027sci3.html|accessdate=18 March 2015|doi=10.1021/cen-v080n027.p030}} Together, the two collections contain more than 90 paintings and 200 works on paper illustrating the work of alchemists and their influence on the development of chemistry as a science.{{cite web|last1=DiMeo|first1=Michelle|title=First Monday Library Chat: Chemical Heritage Foundation|url=http://recipes.hypotheses.org/4845|website=The Recipes Project|accessdate=19 March 2015}} =====Instrument collections===== The Chemical Heritage Foundation's collections include such pioneering and landmark instruments as a 1934 [[Beckman Coulter|Beckman]] Model G pH Meter, a [[DuPont]] 900 Differential Thermal Analyzer, an early custom Electro-spray Ionization Mass Spectrometer used by [[John B. Fenn]], a 1947 [[Mettler Toledo|Mettler]] B5 Single-Pan Balance, a 1963 [[Perkin-Elmer]] Model 125 Infrared Grating Spectrophotometer, and a c. 1980's Automated Peptide Synthesizer created by [[Bruce Merrifield]]. The foundation expanded its instrument collections slowly, mostly through donations of single instruments or small groups of instruments. In 2000, the CIMG was transformed into the Heritage Council Instruments and Artifacts Committee (HCIAC), which included staff and supporters and began meeting under founding chair W. Richard Howe.{{cite web|title=W. Richard Howe|url=http://www.as.pitt.edu/about/w-richard-howe|publisher=University of Pittsburgh|accessdate=18 March 2015}} In 2002, the institution was given hundreds of [[Scientific instrument|instruments]] by Stephen P. DeFalco, president of [[PerkinElmer]], after the company closed a plant in Überlingen, Germany.{{cite journal|title=Perkin-Elmer donates analytical instruments to collection|journal=Pharmaceutical Technology Europe|date=2002|volume=14|issue=9|page=10|url=http://www.chemheritage.org/about/news-and-press/chf-in-the-media/2002-09-01-perkinelmer-donates-analytical-instruments.aspx|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160712034109/http://www.chemheritage.org/about/news-and-press/chf-in-the-media/2002-09-01-perkinelmer-donates-analytical-instruments.aspx|archivedate=July 12, 2016}} An interim exhibition of ''Revolutionary Tools'' was curated at the Chemical Heritage Foundation by David Brock, showing fifteen 20th-century instruments, including Arnold Beckman's pH meter.{{cite journal|last1=Brock|first1=David|title=Revolutionary Tools: Instruments and the Transformation of the Chemical Sciences|journal=Chemical Heritage|date=2002|volume=20|issue=3|page=39}} In 2004, a list of "50 Instruments That Changed the World" was identified as a basis for further expansion. In 2008, the institution released a list of its ten most wanted instruments.{{cite journal|title=CHF's Most Wanted|journal=Chemical Heritage|date=2008|volume=26|issue=2|page=16}} ===== The Arnold O. Beckman Permanent Exhibit and the Clifford C. Hach Gallery ===== As early as 1996, the Chemical Heritage Foundation had envisioned a broadly-based museum of chemical progress in which instruments would have "a major, but not exclusive role".{{cite journal|title=A Museum at CHF? |journal=Chemical Heritage|date=1996|volume=13|issue=2|pages=8–9}} That vision was followed when Peter Saylor of [[Charles E. Dagit, Jr.|Dagit•Saylor Architects]] created the public museum and conference space.{{cite web|title=25 June 08: Chemical substance|url=http://phillyskyline.com/archive_0806b.htm|website=Philly Skyline|accessdate=17 March 2015}} The Arnold O. Beckman Permanent Exhibit and the Clifford C. Hach Gallery for rotating exhibitions opened in 2008. The [[Arnold O. Beckman]] permanent exhibition, ''Making Modernity'', was designed by [[Ralph Appelbaum Associates]]. It has been described as an "art gallery for science", and showcases objects from the institution's widely varying collections. "The instruments are only a fraction of the objects on display. The exhibition also includes books, documents, and artwork from CHF's collection, as well as an array of consumer products."{{cite journal|last1=Arnaud|first1=Celia Henry|title=The Art of Science: Chemical Heritage Foundation takes a new approach to science museums|journal=Chemical & Engineering News|date=October 27, 2008|volume=86|issue=43|pages=34–36|url=http://cen.acs.org/magazine/86/8643.html|accessdate=17 March 2015|doi=10.1021/cen-v086n043.p034}} The exhibition is organized around thematic arcs illustrative of the history of science, particularly chemistry. Displays include the influence of alchemy in early chemistry, the development of the first plastics, the development of brilliantly colored synthetic dyes, scientific advocacy for public health in the 19th and 20th centuries, and the teaching of chemistry through books and chemistry sets.{{cite journal|last1=Greco|first1=JoAnn|title=Making Modernity: A Gallery Preview|journal=Chemical Heritage Magazine|date=2008|volume=26|issue=1|pages=21–25| url=https://www.sciencehistory.org/distillations/magazine/making-modernity-a-gallery-preview|accessdate=10 March 2015}} ===Science History Institute=== On December 1, 2015, the Chemical Heritage Foundation merged with the [[Life Sciences Foundation]], also founded by Arnold Thackray. Recognizing that the joint organization's interests extended beyond the field of chemistry, the organization began a two-year renaming process, whose outcome required the agreement of its founding partners, the [[American Chemical Society]] and the [[American Institute of Chemical Engineers]]. On February 1, 2018, the organization was renamed the Science History Institute, to reflect its wider range of historical interests, extending from the chemical sciences and engineering to the life sciences and biotechnology. ===Leaders=== [[Arnold Thackray]], the institution's first president, was awarded the 1983 [[Dexter Award]] for his contributions to the history of chemistry.{{cite web|title=Arnold Thackray 1939–)|url=http://www.scs.illinois.edu/~mainzv/HIST/awards/Dexter%20Papers/ThackrayDexterBioJJB.pdf|publisher=Division of History of Chemistry of the American Chemical Society|accessdate=1 January 2006}}{{cite journal|last1=Baykoucheva|first1=Svetla|title=The Chemical Heritage Foundation: Past, Present, and Future Interview with Arnold Thackray|journal=Chemical Information Bulletin|date=2008|volume=60|issue=2|pages=10–13|url=http://www.acscinf.org/content/chemical-heritage-foundation-past-present-and-future|accessdate=19 March 2015}} Thackray was succeeded by [[Thomas R. Tritton]], under whose leadership (2008-2013) the history of science museum opened to the public in its present location, and the fellowship program expanded.{{cite journal|last=Reisch|first=Marc S.|title=Haverford College President Thomas Tritton Will Take CHF Helm in January|journal=Chemical & Engineering News|date=2007-06-25|volume=85|issue=26|page=11|url=http://www.chemheritage.org/about/news-and-press/chf-in-the-media/2007-6-25-thomas-tritton-will-take-chf-helm.aspx |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160712194722/http://www.chemheritage.org/about/news-and-press/chf-in-the-media/2007-6-25-thomas-tritton-will-take-chf-helm.aspx|archivedate=July 12, 2016}} {{cite web|last=Gussman|first=Neil|title=Tritton to retire in June 2013|url=http://www.chemheritage.org/about/news-and-press/press-releases/2012-10-09-tritton-announces-plans-to-retire.aspx|publisher=Chemical Heritage Foundation|date=2012-10-09|accessdate=26 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160712194153/http://www.chemheritage.org/about/news-and-press/press-releases/2012-10-09-tritton-announces-plans-to-retire.aspx|archivedate=July 12, 2016}} Following a global search, [[Carsten Reinhardt]], a professor of the history of science from [[Bielefeld University]], Germany, was chosen in August 2013 as President and CEO of the organization.{{cite web|title=Chemical Heritage Foundation Names Carsten Reinhardt CEO|url=http://www.chemicalprocessing.com/industrynews/2013/chemical-heritage-foundation-names-carsten-reinhardt-president-and-ceo/|publisher=Chemical Processing|date=2013-06-05|accessdate=26 June 2013}} In 2016, Reinhardt returned to Germany, and his place was taken by interim president [[Robert G. W. Anderson]]. On January 11, 2017, it was announced that Anderson would take the job permanently.{{cite news|last1=Everts|first1=Sarah|title=Chemical Heritage Foundation names Robert G. W. Anderson as president and CEO The former director of London’s British Museum will take permanent helm of the chemical history organization|url=http://cen.acs.org/articles/95/web/2017/01/Chemical-Heritage-Foundation-names-Robert-G-W-Anderson-as-president-and-CEO.html|accessdate=17 January 2017|work=Chemical & Engineering News|date=January 12, 2017}} ==Collections== The Science History Institute holds many collections relevant to the history of chemistry. [[File:RCA Model EMT3 desktop electron microscope 2003 033 006.tf.TIF|thumb|upright|RCA Model EMT3 Desktop electron microscope, 1950]] [[File:Bakelite Buttons 2007.068 (66948).jpg|thumb|upright|[[Catalin]] buttons]] [[File:THC 2003.902.116 Charging the Experimental Blast Furnace.tif|upright|thumb|Photograph of Experimental Blast Furnace, Fixed Nitrogen Research Laboratory]] * The Othmer Library: In 2004, the Othmer Library became the steward of the Roy G. Neville Historical Chemical Library, which represents one of the most comprehensive single deposits of books on the history of chemistry in the world. Roughly 6,000 titles in all, the Neville collection comprises materials that date from the late 15th century to the early 20th century and includes many of the most important works in the history of science and technology from this period.{{cite web|url=https://www.sciencehistory.org/rare-books |title=Rare Books |website= Science History Institute|date=2016-06-27 }} * Center for Oral History: The Center for Oral History at the Science History Institute aims to create a collection of comprehensive, professionally edited interviews with leading figures in chemistry and related fields.{{cite web|url=https://oh.sciencehistory.org/ |title=Center for Oral History |website= Science History Institute }} * Archives: The Science History Institute collects, preserves, describes, and makes available the unique, unpublished materials that document the past 200 years of scientific history. The Institute actively collects archival materials from outstanding scientists, industries, and professional organizations. Spanning over 5,000 linear shelf feet, these collections are a major attraction for scholars of the history of chemical and molecular sciences.{{cite web|url=https://www.sciencehistory.org/archives |title=Archives |website = Science History Institute |date=2016-05-31 }} * Photographs: The Science History Institute's Image Archive contains an extensive collection of photographic prints, negatives, and slides reflecting the chemical history of the past century. The Institute currently holds more than 20,000 images of notable chemists, laboratories, industrial scenes, historic gatherings, and chemical artifacts. These images hold considerable interest for scholars, journalists, and publishers who are active in chemistry-related fields. Informal snapshots and personal photos capture notable scientists at work and at play, such as the polymer chemists [[Wallace Carothers]] and [[Carl Shipp Marvel]] on a fishing trip and chemical engineer [[Donald Othmer]] and his wife on their wedding day. Highlights include: ** Williams Haynes Portrait Collection: nearly 1,000 formal portraits of important chemists from the early 1900s ** Travis Hignett Collection: images from the Fixed Nitrogen Research Laboratory (1920–1950) ** Joseph Labovsky Collection: the history of nylon ** Dow Historical Collection: 20th-century industrial images {{cite web|url=https://www.sciencehistory.org/photographs |title=Photographs |website= Science History Institute |date=2016-05-31 }} * Fine Art: Strengths of the Science History Institute's fine-art collection include the Fisher Scientific International Collection and the Roy Eddleman Collection, more than 90 paintings and 200 works on paper that unmask the world of the alchemists. In their pursuit of the elusive philosophers’ stone, alchemists created a body of knowledge about the material world through experiments and lab work, setting the stage for modern chemistry. Other highlights of the fine-art collection include oil paintings depicting such early modern chemical activities as distillation and metallurgy and watercolors showing the production process of the textile [[ramie]].{{cite web|url=https://www.sciencehistory.org/fine-art |title=Fine Art|website= Science History Institute |date=2016-05-31}} * Artifacts: The Science History Institute collects three-dimensional artifacts to create a representative group of material-culture objects that can be used as resources for both research and exhibition. The Institute holds a variety of historical artifacts related to chemistry and chemical education, including instrumentation. It has one of the best public collections of chemistry sets, with approximately 100 different sets from all over the world, including Australia and Germany. Other special artifact collections include The Beauty of [[Bakelite]] and Chemistry and Fashion. Highlights include the Beckman IR-1 [[spectrophotometer]], [[John Fenn (chemist)|John Fenn]]’s electrospray mass spectrometer and [[Bruce Merrifield]]’s solid-phase peptide synthesizer.{{cite web|url=https://www.sciencehistory.org/objects |title=Objects | website= Science History Institute |date=2016-05-31 }} File:Pandora, das ist 1582 Die Gab Gottes p 247 AQ5 (2).jpg|''Pandora, das ist, Die edleste Gab Gottes'', 1582 File:The Alchemist’s Experiment Takes Fire 1687 CHF fa 2000.001.276.JPG|''The Alchemist’s Experiment Takes Fire'', 1687 File:Trouble Comes to the Alchemist FA 2000.001.269.jpg|''Trouble Comes to the Alchemist'' ==''Distillations''== The Science History Institute's magazine, ''Distillations'', appears three times a year. It presents stories about the history of science for a popular readership. ''Distillations'' first appeared in spring 2015, as a publication of the Chemical Heritage Foundation. It was predated by the ''Chemical Heritage Magazine'', published as a quarterly by the Chemical Heritage Foundation.{{cite web |url=https://www.sciencehistory.org/distillations/about |title=Distillations: About |publisher=Science History Institute|accessdate=June 15, 2017|date=2016-07-05 }} ==Fellowships== The Science History Institute offers many fellowships-in-residence, of varying lengths.{{cite web|url=https://www.sciencehistory.org/fellowships |title=Fellowships |website= Science History Institute |date=2016-05-31 }} ==Awards== The Science History Institute presents a number of annual awards to recognize outstanding contributions to science and technology by researchers, business leaders and entrepreneurs.{{cite web|url=https://www.sciencehistory.org/awards-program|title= Science History Institute Awards Program|website= Science History Institute|accessdate = 24 March 2018|date= 2016-06-27}} The annual Heritage Day Awards honor achievements in science and technology and comprise the [[Othmer Gold Medal]],{{cite web|title=Othmer Gold Medal|url=https://www.sciencehistory.org/othmer-gold-medal|website=Science History Institute|accessdate=23 March 2018|date=2016-05-31}} the [[Richard J. Bolte Sr. Award|Richard J. Bolte Sr. Award for Supporting Industries]]{{cite web|title=Richard J. Bolte Sr. Award for Supporting Industries|url=https://www.sciencehistory.org/richard-j-bolte-sr-award-for-supporting-industries|website=Science History Institute|accessdate=23 March 2018|date=2016-05-31}} and, in conjunction with [[The Chemists' Club]] of New York, the [[Winthrop-Sears Medal]].{{cite web|title=Winthrop-Sears Medal|url=https://www.sciencehistory.org/winthrop-sears-medal|website=Science History Institute|accessdate=23 March 2018|date=2016-05-31}} The annual Affiliate Partnership Awards, presented in conjunction with affiliate organizations, recognize achievement with the [[Biotechnology Heritage Award]],{{cite web|title=Biotechnology Heritage Award|url=https://www.sciencehistory.org/biotechnology-heritage-award|website=Science History Institute|accessdate=24 March 2018|date=2016-05-31}} the Franklin-Lavoisier Prize,{{cite web|title=Franklin-Lavoisier Prize|url=https://www.sciencehistory.org/franklin-lavoisier-prize|website=Science History Institute|accessdate=24 March 2018|date=2016-05-31}} the [[Petrochemical Heritage Award]]{{cite web|title=Petrochemical Heritage Award|url=https://www.sciencehistory.org/petrochemical-heritage-award|website=Science History Institute|accessdate=24 March 2018|date=2016-05-31}} and the [[Pittcon Heritage Award]].{{cite web|title=Pittcon Heritage Award|url=https://www.sciencehistory.org/pittcon-heritage-award|website=Science History Institute|accessdate=23 March 2018|date=2016-05-31}} The [[Roy G. Neville Prize]] in Bibliography or Biography recognizes a biographical work in the field of chemical or molecular science. Established in 2006, the prize is awarded biennially.{{cite web|title=Roy G. Neville Prize in Bibliography or Biography |url=https://www.sciencehistory.org/roy-g-neville-prize|website=Science History Institute|accessdate=23 March 2018|date=2016-07-05}} ==See also== * [[Burndy Library]] * [[Harvard Collection of Historical Scientific Instruments]] * [[Whipple Museum of the History of Science]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category}} * {{Official website|http://www.sciencehistory.org/ }} {{Philadelphia}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:1982 establishments in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Heritage organizations]] [[Category:History of chemistry]] [[Category:History of science museums]] [[Category:Museums in Philadelphia]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1982]] [[Category:Science museums in Pennsylvania]]

[[Image:Japanese school uniform dsc06051.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Japan]]ese high school students wearing the [[sailor fuku]]]] {{Outdated|date=September 2016}} '''Secondary education in Japan''' is split into [[junior high school]]s (中学校 ''chūgakkō''), which cover the seventh through ninth grade, and [[senior high school]]s (高等学校 ''kōtōgakkō'', abbreviated to 高校 ''kōkō''), which mostly cover grades ten through twelve.
==Junior high school== [[Image:Japanese Middle School.jpg|thumb|right|The courtyard and classrooms wing of [https://web.archive.org/web/20070927003457/http://www3.saga-ed.jp/school/oni-tyu/ Onizuka Junior High School] (鬼塚中学校) in [[Karatsu, Saga|Karatsu]], [[Japan]]]] [[File:Japanese_classroom.jpg|alt=Picture of a typical Japanese classroom|left|thumb|335x335px|A typical Japanese classroom]] Lower-secondary schools cover grades seven, eight, and nine. Ages are roughly 12-15 with increased focus on academic studies. Although it is possible to leave the formal education system after completing lower secondary school and find employment, fewer than 4% did so by the late 1980s.
Most junior high schools in the 1980s were government-funded public schools; 5% were private schools. At ¥552,592 ($3,989 USD) per pupil, private schools had a per-student cost that was four times higher than public schools, at ¥130,828 ($934 USD).<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/957970329|title=Insights from emergent education systems in selected countries : with De La Salle-College of Saint Benilde School of Multidisciplinary Studies scenarios upon full implementation of the K-12 program by 2016.|last=A.|first=Fadul, Jose|date=2011|publisher=Lulu Press, Inc|isbn=9781257995219|location=Morrisville, North Carolina|oclc=957970329}}</ref>
The minimum number of school days in a year is 210 in Japan, compared to 180 in the United States. However, students will typically attend school for 240 to 250 days a year. A significant part of the school calendar is taken up by non-academic events such as sports days and school trips.<ref name="Shields2004">{{cite book|first=James J.|last=Shields|title=Japanese Schooling: Patterns of Socialization, Equality, and Political Control|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ssHlZQvhOA4C&pg=PA82|accessdate=16 November 2012|date=31 May 2004|publisher=Penn State Press|isbn=978-0-271-02340-3|pages=82–84}}</ref>
Teachers often majored in the subjects they taught. Each class is assigned a homeroom teacher who doubles as [[school counselor|counselor]]. Unlike [[Elementary school|elementary]] students, junior high school students have different teachers for different subjects. The subject teachers usually move to a new room for each 50-minute period. Usually students' lunch is provided by the school itself.
===Instruction=== [[Image:Japanese-Teacher's-Room.jpg|left|thumbnail|250px|A teachers' room at Onizuka [[Junior High School]] in [[Karatsu, Saga|Karatsu]], [[Japan]] (classes usually stay in one place and teachers move each period)]]
Instruction tends to rely on the [[lecture]] method.{{Citation needed|date=January 2008}} Teachers also use other media, such as [[television]] and [[radio]], and there is some [[laboratory]] work. By 1989 about 45% of all public lower-secondary schools had computers, including schools that used them only for administrative purposes. Classroom organization is still based on small work groups, although no longer for reasons of discipline. Students are expected to have mastered daily routines and acceptable behavior.
All course contents are specified in the [[curriculum|Course of Study for Lower-Secondary Schools]]. Some subjects, such as [[Japanese language]] and [[mathematics]], are coordinated with the elementary [[curriculum]]. The curriculum covers Japanese language, English, social studies, mathematics, science, music, fine arts, industrial arts, homemaking, health, and physical education. [[Morality|Moral]] education and special activities continue to receive attention.<ref>[http://www.tnr.com/article/world/85463/japan-nuclear-power-regulation With a Mighty Hand], ''New Republic'', March 19, 2011.</ref>
===Extracurricular activities===
Many students participate in after-school clubs. Sports clubs, such as [[baseball in Japan|baseball]] are especially popular among boys,<ref name="web-japan.org">http://web-japan.org/kidsweb/explore/schools/index.html</ref><ref name="springer.com">[https://www.springer.com/education+%26+language/book/978-94-007-2177-7 Wind Bands and Cultural Identity in Japanese Schools] by David G. Hebert (Springer press, 2011).</ref> while wind bands are the most popular club for girls.<ref name="springer.com"/> Soccer (football) clubs are gaining popularity. [[Judo]] clubs attract boys and girls. They may be inspired by the many Japanese judo athletes who have won medals at the World Judo Championships and the Olympic Games. Other popular sports clubs include tennis, basketball, gymnastics, and volleyball. In every sport, many games are held between schools and at the regional level, so students have opportunities to compete.
For cultural clubs, one that has gained popularity is the [[Go (game)|go club]]. Go is a strategic board game played with black and white stones. After a manga about the game was published (''[[Hikaru no Go]]''), more schoolchildren started enjoying go. Other options for students include choir and art clubs. Brass band, tea ceremony, and flower arrangement clubs are popular.<ref name="web-japan.org"/>
Some junior high schools encourage students to take academic ability tests such as the [[STEP Eiken]] for English or the [[Kanji kentei]] for Japanese.
Students in the highest grades of elementary, junior high, and senior high schools also take trips lasting up to several days to culturally important cities such as Kyoto and Nara, ski resorts, or other places.<ref name="web-japan.org"/>
==Senior high school== [[File:Kanagawa highschool class.jpg|thumb|A high school class in 1963]]
Even though [[upper secondary school|upper-secondary school]] is not compulsory in Japan, as of 2005 94% of all junior high school graduates entered high schools<ref>STATISTICAL ABSTRACT 2006 edition<{{cite web |url=http://www.mext.go.jp/english/statist/index.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-06-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080617061845/http://www.mext.go.jp/english/statist/index.htm |archivedate=2008-06-17 |df= }}></ref> and over 95% of students graduated successfully from them compared to 89% of Americans.<ref name="unc.edu">http://www.unc.edu/world/2006_K12Symp/Post-Program/Middle_Lesson_Plan.pdf</ref>
To enter, students must take an [[entrance examination]] in Japanese, mathematics, science, social studies, and English,<ref name="ericdigests.org">Marcia, Johnson L. and Jeffrey R. Johnson. "[http://www.ericdigests.org/1997-4/daily.htm Daily Life in Japanese High Schools]." ''[[ERIC Digest]]''. October 1996. [[ERIC]] Identifier: ED406301.</ref> whether it is standardized for all public high schools in the prefecture or a test created by a private high school for that school alone.<ref name="ericdigests.org"/> All upper-secondary schools, public and private, are informally ranked based on their success in placing graduates in freshman classes of [[List of universities in Japan#By_ranking|internationally ranked]] and [[Imperial Universities]].<ref name="ericdigests.org"/> Success or failure on an entrance examination can influence a student's entire future, since the prospect of finding a good job depends on the school attended.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} Thus, students experience the pressure of this examination system at a relatively early age.<ref name="ericdigests.org"/> Because of the importance of these exams in entering high school — even more than the scholastic record and performance evaluations from lower-secondary school — students are closely counselled in lower-secondary school so that they will be relatively assured of a place in the schools to which they apply.
===Daily life===
Students walk, ride bicycles, or take public transportation to school.<ref name="ericdigests.org"/> It is not uncommon for students to spend two or more hours each day on public transportation,<ref name="ericdigests.org"/> taking time to sleep, study or socialize. What they can do on the way to and from school — chewing gum, consuming snacks, reading books while walking — anything that might reflect badly on the reputation of the school<ref name="ericdigests.org"/> is heavily regulated to protect that reputation.<ref name="ericdigests.org"/> Some schools even require students to leave seats open on buses and trains for other passengers "to demonstrate consideration."<ref name="ericdigests.org"/> Each school has a unique uniform that makes its students easily identifiable to the public.<ref name="ericdigests.org"/>
Every high school has a set of lockers for students to exchange their street shoes for a set of slippers, which in some schools are color-coded for gender.<ref name="ericdigests.org"/>
High schools typically begin at 8:30,<ref name="ericdigests.org"/> when teachers meet for a five-minute meeting, followed by homeroom.<ref name="members.tripod.com">http://members.tripod.com/h_javora/jed8.htm</ref> Students assemble in their homerooms of an average of between 40 and 45 students each,<ref name="ericdigests.org"/> with some schools having a weekly schoolwide assembly beforehand.<ref name="ericdigests.org"/> Homeroom teachers are in charge of morning and afternoon homeroom times, both about five minutes each,<ref name="members.tripod.com"/> as well as a weekly one-hour long homeroom period.<ref name="Century, Miki Y 2005, p. 101">Japanese Education in the 21st Century, Miki Y. Ishikida, June 2005, p. 101</ref>
The latter meeting "provides an opportunity for teachers to concentrate on student guidance. Typical activities include helping students develop greater awareness of themselves as high school students, encouraging them to reflect on their summer vacations, or perhaps asking them to contemplate the forthcoming advancement from one grade to another. These discussion topics are planned by teachers and scheduled in advance for the entire school year."<ref name="members.tripod.com"/>
During the daily homerooms the students themselves conduct what they call "toban" — taking attendance, making announcements, etc. — that are shared on a rotating basis.<ref name="ericdigests.org"/> Two class leaders, one male and one female are elected every trimester, and many students are assigned to specific task committees in their homeroom class.<ref name="Century, Miki Y 2005, p. 101"/>
Regular classes begin at 8:45 AM and there are four classes of 50 minutes each before lunch.<ref name="members.tripod.com"/> Students go to different classrooms for physical education, laboratory classes, or other specialized courses; otherwise, teachers change classrooms instead of the students for the entire day.<ref name="ericdigests.org"/> Students typically attend between ten and fourteen courses a year;<ref>http://www.mangatutorials.com/tut/jschool2.php</ref> however, "you don't have all of your classes every day. The schedule rotates throughout the week, and in every classroom you enter you will find a schedule taped to the wall."<ref name="Century, Miki Y 2005, p. 101"/>
Most schools do not have their own cafeteria,<ref name="ericdigests.org"/> students eating in their homerooms instead,<ref name="members.tripod.com"/> and unlike elementary and middle schools high schoolers do not have government-subsidized lunches.<ref name="Century, Miki Y 2005, p. 101"/> Because of this many students bring a box lunch (bento) - from home with foods such as rice, fish, eggs, vegetables, and pickles.<ref name="ericdigests.org"/><ref name="Century, Miki Y 2005, p. 101"/>
After lunch students have two more classes.<ref name="members.tripod.com"/> All students then participate in a fifteen-minute cleaning the school ("osoji").<ref name="ericdigests.org"/><ref name="Century, Miki Y 2005, p. 101"/> The students work in assigned groups of between four and six students, known as han, to clean their classrooms, corridors, and school grounds.<ref name="Century, Miki Y 2005, p. 101"/>
After osoji and the afternoon homeroom meeting, or at 3:30 PM, students are free to attend extracurricular activities.<ref name="ericdigests.org"/><ref name="members.tripod.com"/>
Saturday schooling, when offered, ends at 1 PM after four courses.<ref name="members.tripod.com"/> (As discussed below, Saturday courses were officially done away with in 2002 but many schools have either kept them or are trying to bring them back).
====Extracurriculars====
In most schools, there are two types of extracurricular clubs: * sports clubs, such as [[baseball]], [[football]], [[judo]], [[kendo]], [[track and field|track]], [[tennis]], [[swimming (sport)|swimming]], [[softball]], [[volleyball]], and [[rugby football|rugby]]; * culture clubs, such as [[English language|English]], [[broadcasting]], [[calligraphy]], [[science]], [[mathematics]], and [[yearbook]].<ref name="ericdigests.org"/>
New students usually choose a club after the school year begins and only rarely change for the rest of their high school careers.<ref name="ericdigests.org"/> Clubs meet for two hours after school every day, many times even during school vacations.<ref name="ericdigests.org"/> Although there is a teacher assigned to each club as a sponsor, they often have very little input in the club's daily activities.<ref name="ericdigests.org"/> These clubs are an important chance for students to make friends and learn the social etiquette and relationships like the "senpai" (senior)/"kohai" (junior) dynamic that will be important in their adult lives.<ref name="ericdigests.org"/>
However, most college bound students withdraw from club activities during their senior year to devote more time to preparation for university entrance examinations.<ref name="ericdigests.org"/> Homeroom teachers work with students and their parents at this time to discuss their admission prospects or career plans.<ref name="Century, Miki Y 2005, p. 101"/>
====Free time====
Outside of school and [[cram schools]], research done in the late 1990s showed students doing approximately two hours of homework on weekdays and about three hours of it on Sundays.<ref name="ericdigests.org"/> Every day students spent an average of two hours watching [[television]], 30 minutes listening to the [[radio]], an hour reading for fun, and less than half an hour hanging out with peers.<ref name="ericdigests.org"/> Parents and teachers strongly discourage teenage dating, and most young people do not begin to do so until after high school.<ref name="ericdigests.org"/> More recently, social media such as [[Line (software)|Line]] are popular.
===Curriculum===
As of the late 1990s Japanese students spent 240 days a year at school, 60 days more than their American counterparts<ref name="ericdigests.org"/> even with the amount of time spent preparing for school festivals and events.<ref name="Shields2004"/><ref name="ericdigests.org"/> Traditionally Japanese students attended class on Saturdays;<ref name="ericdigests.org"/> although education reforms from 2002 have made them no longer mandatory,<ref name="unc.edu"/> many schools have begun to bring them back to have more time to cover the rigorous material required by the Ministry of Education.{{citation needed|date=November 2018}}
Schools have limited autonomy in developing their curriculum or choosing their textbooks. Instead, although the latter are written and produced in the private sector,<ref name="unc.edu"/> the Ministry of Education has the final say over any and all content and materials.<ref name="ericdigests.org"/> Typically students take three years each of [[mathematics]], [[social studies]], [[Japanese studies|Japanese]], [[science]], and [[English as a second or foreign language|English]], with additional courses including [[physical education]], [[music]], [[art]], and moral studies.<ref name="unc.edu"/> In particular [[social studies]] in Japan is broken down into [[civics]], [[geography]], Japanese history, world history, [[sociology]], and [[politics]]/[[economics]].<ref name="unc.edu"/>
Because the amount of mandatory courses, electives are few. All the students in one grade level study the same subjects,<ref name="ericdigests.org"/> although it is in upper-secondary school that differences in ability are first publicly acknowledged.
Most upper-secondary teachers are university graduates. Upper-secondary schools are organized into departments, and teachers specialize in their major fields although they teach a variety of courses within their disciplines. Teaching depends largely on the lecture system, with the main goal of covering the very demanding curriculum in the time allotted. Approach and subject coverage tends to be uniform, at least in the public schools.
===Types of schools=== {{Update|section|date=January 2014}}
====General program====
The most common type of upper-secondary schools has a full-time, general program that offered academic courses for students preparing for [[higher education in Japan|higher education]].
According to 2005 research, while almost 90% of Japanese students attend public schools from kindergarten through the ninth grade, over 29% of students go to private high schools.<ref name="unc.edu"/> A late-1980s study by the [[Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology|Ministry of Education]] had found that families paid about [[Japanese yen|¥]]300,000 (US$2,142) a year for a public high school and about twice as much for a private high school; however, as the name suggests, the 2010 "Act on Free Tuition Fee at Public High Schools and High School Enrollment Support Fund" did away with all public high school tuition.<ref>[http://www.mext.go.jp/english/elsec/1303524.htm]</ref>
Besides being free to attend, public schools are more popular because many students and experts have found the quality of education to be much better than that at private schools.<ref name=Reedp119>Reed, p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=cXplmWOycwEC&pg=PA119&lpg=PA119 119].</ref> Because of this entrance exams for public high schools are much more competitive among students than their private counterparts.
Japanese [[vocational education|vocational and technical]] programs include several hundred specialized courses, such as information processing, metal works, fish farming, business English, and automotive industry. Business and industrial courses in particular accounted for 72% of all students in full-time vocational programs in 1989.
The first-year programs for students in both academic and commercial courses are similar. They include basic academic courses, such as [[Japanese language]], [[English language|English]], [[mathematics]], and [[science]].
Training of disabled students, particularly at the upper-secondary level, emphasizes vocational education to enable students to be as independent as possible within society. Vocational training varies considerably depending on the student's disability, but the options are limited for some. It is clear that the government is aware of the necessity of broadening the range of possibilities for these students. Advancement to higher education is also a goal of the government, and it struggles to have institutions of higher learning accept more students with disabilities.
====Nontraditional schools====
A small number of schools offer part-time classes, [[night school]], or [[correspondence education]].
==Education reforms== {{TIMSSScores2007}} {{See also|Curriculum guideline|Yutori education}}
The [[Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology]] (MEXT) recognizes a need to improve the teaching of all [[foreign language]]s, especially English. To improve instruction in spoken [[English language|English]], the [[Government of Japan|government]] invites many young native speakers of English to Japan to serve as assistants to school [[board of education|board]]s and [[Prefectures of Japan|prefectures]] under its [[Jet Programme|Japan Exchange and Teaching Program]]. By 2005 participants numbered over 6,000. In the last few years, several school boards in Japan have relied on ALTs ([[Assistant Language Teacher]]) from private dispatch companies.
As part of the movement to develop an integrated curriculum and the education reform movement of the late 1980s, the entire Course of Study for Lower-Secondary Schools was revised in 1989 and took effect in the 1992–93 school year. A main aim of the reform is to equip students with the basic knowledge needed for [[citizenship]]. In some measure, this means increased emphasis on [[History of Japan|Japanese history]] and [[Culture of Japan|culture]], as well as understanding Japan as a nation and its relationships with other nations of the world. The course of study also increased elective hours, recommending that electives be chosen in light of individual student differences and with an eye toward diversification.
A further revision to the [[Fundamental Law of Education]] was carried out on 22 December 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mext.go.jp/english/lawandplan/1303462.htm|title=MEXT : Basic Act on Education (Provisional translation)|publisher=The Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology|accessdate=April 19, 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160331133057/http://www.mext.go.jp/english/lawandplan/1303462.htm|archivedate=March 31, 2016|df=}}</ref> The revised law leaves the structure of schooling basically the same but includes new emphases on respect for [[Culture of Japan|Japanese culture]] (Article 2.5), school [[discipline]] (Article 6.2), and [[parent]]al [[Moral responsibility|responsibility]] (Article 10).<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090220064548/http://japanfocus.org/images/UserFiles/File/2468.lebowitzMcNeill.education/ed.law.file.pdf Comparison of old and current law] on Japan Focus an Asian Pacific e-journal] accessed at December 11, 2008</ref>
===Junior high issues===
Two problems of great concern to educators and citizens began to appear at the lower-secondary level in the 1980s: [[bullying]], which remains a major problem, and the [[school refusal|school-refusal syndrome]] (toko kyohi; manifested by excessive [[truancy|absenteeism]]), which was on the rise.<ref>[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9507E0DA133EF931A25752C0A9659C8B63&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=all Free to Be] by Miki Tanikawa, ''[[The New York Times]]'' January 12, 2002</ref> In 2008, there were 42,754 incidents of problematic behavior in junior high schools, according to a government survey.<ref>''[[Yomiuri Shimbun]]'' 2/12/2009</ref>
Experts disagreed over the specific causes of these phenomena, but there is general agreement that the system offers little individualized or specialized assistance, thus contributing to disaffection among those who can not conform to its demands or who are otherwise experiencing difficulties. Another problem concerns Japanese children returning from abroad. These students, particularly if they have been overseas for extended periods, often need help in reading and writing — and in adjusting to rigid classroom demands. Even making the adjustment does not guarantee acceptance. Besides having acquired a foreign language, many of these students have also acquired foreign customs of speech, dress, and behavior that mark them as different.
===Senior high issues===
The upper-secondary curriculum underwent thorough revision in 1989. That year a new [[Course of Study for Upper-Secondary Schools]] was announced that was to be phased in beginning with the tenth grade in 1994, followed by the eleventh grade in 1995 and the twelfth grade in 1996. Among noteworthy changes is the requirement that male and female students take a course in [[Family and consumer science|home economics]]. The government is concerned with instilling in all students an awareness of the importance of [[Japanese family|family life]], the roles and responsibilities of family members, the concept of cooperation within the family, and the role of the family in society. The family continues to be an extremely important part of the social infrastructure, and the ministry clearly is interested in maintaining family stability within a changing society. Another change of note was the division of the old [[social studies]] course into ''[[history]]-and-[[geography]]'' and ''[[civics]]'' courses.
== See also == * [[Education in Japan]] ** [[Educational reform in occupied Japan]] ** [[Higher education in Japan]]

[[File:Omni-Theatre, Singapore Science Centre, Nov 05.JPG|thumb|Omni-Theatre, Singapore Science Centre, Singapore]] [[File:IMAX Dome control room.jpg|thumb|Interior of an IMAX Dome control room Science Centre OMNI-Theatre, Republic of Singapore]] The '''Singapore Omni-Theatre''' is an observatory and large-format film theatre located in the [[Science Centre, Singapore]] in the city-state [[Singapore]], South-east Asia. It opened in 1977. The Science Centre houses more than 850 exhibits, mostly interactive; the largest collection devoted to science in the city.<ref>[http://www.iexplore.com/cityguides/Singapore/Singapore+City/Where+to+Go Where to Go in Singapore City] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071106093749/http://www.iexplore.com/cityguides/Singapore/Singapore+City/Where+to+Go |date=2007-11-06 }}</ref>
==Facilities== As part of the larger Science Centre, it specifically encompasses an [[observatory]], an omniplanetarium, and an domed projection system to show movies relating to [[science]], [[astronomy]], etc. A simulation theatre, exhibition room, class room, restaurant, and gift shop are also located on the premises.
==The Observatory== As one of the few observatories in the world located next to the [[Equator]], [[constellations]] in both the northern and southern celestial hemispheres can be observed and thus opens up more vistas in the sky for observers.
The main [[telescope]] of the Observatory is a 40-cm Cassegrain reflector of combined focal length 520-cm. The sub-telescope is a 15-cm apochromatic Kepler refractor of focal length 180-cm. The equatorial mount for the telescopes was designed for its location; the accompanying English yoke] provides the necessary stability for the drive and tracking mechanisms. The 5.5-metre stainless steel [[dome]] can be made to swivel in any direction and its shutter can be made to slide open for the telescope to be focused onto interesting objects in the sky.
The observatory is situated at geographical coordinates: 1o 20' 03" N latitude 103o 44' 14" E longitude 15.27 m Height (m.s.l)
==The theatre== The theatre consists of a massive hemispheric screen, twenty-three metres in diameter. This screen is sixteen metres or about five storeys high, and is made up of 376 pieces of vinyl-coated [[aluminium]] panels, covering a surface of 625 m². The material achieves 30% reflectivity, ensuring immense clarity.
About 43 million perforations in the screen allow both sound and air-conditioning to pass through to the audience. Stretching 180 degrees horizontal from wall to wall and tilted at a 30-degree angle to the horizon, the screen "wraps" over the audience to cover 80% of a hemisphere so that the images far exceed a person's field of vision.<ref>[http://www.science.edu.sg/ssc/otmovie.jsp?type=8&root=0&parent=0&cat=383 Singapore Science Centre: Omni-Theatre|IMAX Screen & Technology<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071116074956/http://www.science.edu.sg/ssc/otmovie.jsp?type=8&root=0&parent=0&cat=383 |date=2007-11-16 }}</ref> The theatre seats 276 and was the first in Southeast Asia.
